title: Acts Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 3.

questions.question: At what hour did Peter and John go up to the temple to pray?
questions.correctAnswer: The ninth hour
questions.explanation: Acts 3:1 states that Peter and John went up to the temple at the ninth hour.

questions.question: Where was the man who was lame from birth laid daily to ask for alms?
options: The gate of the temple treasury
questions.correctAnswer: The Beautiful gate
questions.explanation: Acts 3:2 describes that the lame man was laid at the gate called Beautiful.

questions.question: What did the lame man do when he saw Peter and John going into the temple?
questions.correctAnswer: Asked for alms
questions.explanation: Acts 3:3 says the lame man asked Peter and John for alms.

questions.question: What did Peter say he had to give the lame man?
options: In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth rise up and walk
questions.correctAnswer: In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth rise up and walk
questions.explanation: Acts 3:6 shows Peter saying he had no silver or gold but gave healing in Jesus’ name.

questions.question: What happened immediately after Peter took the lame man by the right hand?
options: His feet and ankle bones received strength
He was taken away by the crowd
questions.correctAnswer: His feet and ankle bones received strength
questions.explanation: Acts 3:7 tells that the man’s feet and ankle bones received strength immediately.

questions.question: How did the lame man enter the temple after being healed?
options: Walking and leaping and praising God
questions.correctAnswer: Walking and leaping and praising God
questions.explanation: Acts 3:8 says he entered the temple walking, leaping, and praising God.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the people when they saw the healed man?
options: They were filled with wonder and amazement
They questioned Peter and John angrily
questions.correctAnswer: They were filled with wonder and amazement
questions.explanation: Acts 3:10 states the people were amazed at what happened to the man.

questions.question: Where did all the people run together after the healing?
questions.correctAnswer: The porch called Solomon's
questions.explanation: Acts 3:11 mentions the people running to the porch called Solomon's.

questions.question: According to Peter, by what power was the man healed?
options: Faith in the name of Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Faith in the name of Jesus
questions.explanation: Acts 3:16 explains the man was made strong through faith in Jesus' name.

questions.question: Who did Peter say was killed and God raised from the dead?
questions.correctAnswer: The Prince of life
questions.explanation: Acts 3:15 refers to Jesus as the Prince of life who was killed and raised.

questions.question: True or False: Peter told the people that their rulers acted with full knowledge when they denied Jesus.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 3:17 shows Peter said they acted through ignorance, not full knowledge.

questions.question: True or False: Peter said that repentance would lead to the blotting out of sins.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 3:19 commands repentance for the blotting out of sins.

questions.question: True or False: The heaven must receive Jesus until the times of restitution of all things.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 3:21 states Jesus must remain in heaven until the times of restitution.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Acts 3:22: 'A prophet shall the Lord your God raise up unto you of your brethren, like unto me; him shall ye ______ in all things whatsoever he shall say unto you.'
questions.correctAnswer: hear
questions.explanation: Acts 3:22 instructs that the prophet raised by God shall be heard in all things.

questions.question: According to Peter, who are the children of the prophets and of the covenant made with Abraham?
questions.correctAnswer: The people of Israel
questions.explanation: Acts 3:25 identifies the people addressed as children of the prophets and covenant with Abraham.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Acts 3 teach us the importance of faith in the power of Jesus Christ when facing challenges in life?
options: Faith in Jesus' name brings healing and strength
Good works alone will solve problems
Only wealth can provide true security
questions.correctAnswer: Faith in Jesus' name brings healing and strength
questions.explanation: Acts 3:6-7 shows that Peter, in faith and in the name of Jesus Christ, healed the lame man, emphasizing that faith in Jesus empowers us to overcome difficulties. This is supported by verses 3:16 and 3:26 which highlight faith and blessings through Jesus.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement because they feel powerless. Based on Acts 3, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Trust in the name of Jesus Christ for strength and healing
Depend on your own abilities to fix problems
Ignore the problem and focus on material gain
Wait for others to solve your difficulties
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the name of Jesus Christ for strength and healing
questions.explanation: Acts 3:6-8 shows Peter telling the lame man that he has no silver or gold, but in the name of Jesus Christ, he is made strong and able to walk. This teaches reliance on Jesus’ power rather than our own.

questions.question: What does Acts 3 teach about humility and acknowledging God's power rather than our own?
options: We should give God glory, not take credit ourselves
We are the source of all good works
We can accomplish miracles by our holiness
Self-praise is encouraged for good deeds
questions.correctAnswer: We should give God glory, not take credit ourselves
questions.explanation: In Acts 3:12, Peter tells the people not to marvel as if by their own power or holiness the man was healed, but that it was God’s power working through faith in Jesus (3:16). This underscores humility and giving glory to God.

questions.question: How does Acts 3 encourage believers to respond when they realize they have sinned unknowingly?
options: Repent and turn to God for forgiveness
Ignore the sin and continue as before
Hide your sin to avoid shame
questions.correctAnswer: Repent and turn to God for forgiveness
questions.explanation: Acts 3:17-19 teaches that even if sins were committed through ignorance, repentance and conversion are necessary for sins to be blotted out and for times of refreshing to come from the Lord.

questions.question: A believer wants to grow in prayer and personal devotion. What example from Acts 3 supports regular prayer discipline?
options: Peter and John went to the temple at the hour of prayer
They avoided public places to pray
They relied on spontaneous, unplanned prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Peter and John went to the temple at the hour of prayer
questions.explanation: Acts 3:1 describes Peter and John going to the temple together at the ninth hour, the hour of prayer, demonstrating disciplined, regular devotion and prayer life.

questions.question: From Acts 3, how should believers approach serving others in the church community?
options: Serve others in faith and humility, recognizing God's power
Serve only those who can repay you
Avoid serving because it is burdensome
questions.correctAnswer: Serve others in faith and humility, recognizing God's power
questions.explanation: Peter’s healing of the lame man (Acts 3:6-8) shows service motivated by faith and humility, giving God glory (3:12), encouraging believers to serve others relying on God's power, not personal merit.

questions.question: What does Acts 3 teach about the role of Jesus Christ in blessing and turning away from sin?
options: Jesus was sent to bless and turn people from iniquities
Jesus is only a moral teacher
Blessings come from wealth and status
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus was sent to bless and turn people from iniquities
questions.explanation: Acts 3:26 explains that God sent His Son Jesus to bless the people by turning them away from their sins, emphasizing Jesus’ role in forgiveness and blessing.

questions.question: According to Acts 3, what should be our attitude toward the prophecy and teaching of Jesus Christ?
options: We must listen and obey the prophet like Moses instructed
We can ignore the teachings without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: We must listen and obey the prophet like Moses instructed
questions.explanation: Acts 3:22-23 quotes Moses saying a prophet like him will be raised and everyone must hear him, warning that not listening leads to destruction, underscoring obedience to Jesus’ teachings.

questions.question: True or False: Peter and John performed the miracle of healing the lame man by their own power and holiness.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 3:12 states Peter told the people the miracle was not by their own power or holiness but by faith in Jesus Christ, emphasizing reliance on God's power rather than human ability.

questions.question: True or False: Repentance leads to times of refreshing and forgiveness according to Acts 3.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 3:19 teaches that repentance and conversion lead to sins being blotted out and times of refreshing from the Lord, highlighting the blessing of repentance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Peter told the lame man, 'Silver and gold have I none; but such as I have give I thee: In the name of ________ Christ of Nazareth rise up and walk.'
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Acts 3:6 records Peter healing the man by the power of Jesus Christ’s name, showing the authority and power in Jesus’ name to bring healing and restoration.

questions.question: How does Acts 3 illustrate the importance of generosity and stewardship in Christian life?
options: Peter gave what he had, the power of Jesus' name, rather than money
Only money can help those in need
Ignoring those in need is acceptable
Generosity is unnecessary if you have no wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Peter gave what he had, the power of Jesus' name, rather than money
questions.explanation: Acts 3:6 shows Peter had no silver or gold but offered the man healing through Jesus’ name, teaching that generosity can be spiritual and does not depend solely on material wealth.

questions.question: What does Acts 3 teach about perseverance through trials and trusting God's plan?
options: God’s prophets foretold suffering but also restoration through Christ
Trials mean God has abandoned us
Suffering is a sign of failure
questions.correctAnswer: God’s prophets foretold suffering but also restoration through Christ
questions.explanation: Acts 3:18-21 explains that Christ’s suffering was foretold by prophets and will be followed by restoration and blessing, encouraging believers to trust God’s plan through trials.

questions.question: How can believers apply the teaching of Acts 3 on forgiveness and reconciliation?
options: By repenting and turning away from sin to receive God's blessing
By holding grudges and refusing to forgive
By ignoring sin and pretending it doesn't exist
By blaming others for personal faults
questions.correctAnswer: By repenting and turning away from sin to receive God's blessing
questions.explanation: Acts 3:19 and 3:26 encourage repentance and conversion so sins may be blotted out and blessings received, highlighting the importance of forgiveness and reconciliation with God.

questions.question: What example does Acts 3 give about honesty and integrity in daily Christian witness?
options: Peter honestly declared the truth of Jesus’ resurrection and rejected false credit for the miracle
Peter exaggerated his own role to gain fame
Peter avoided discussing Jesus' death and resurrection
Peter claimed the miracle was by his own holiness
questions.correctAnswer: Peter honestly declared the truth of Jesus’ resurrection and rejected false credit for the miracle
questions.explanation: Acts 3:12-15 shows Peter openly acknowledging the resurrection of Jesus and denying that the miracle was by his own power, demonstrating integrity and truthful witness.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 3.

questions.question: What is the significance of the temple gate called 'Beautiful' in Acts 3:2-10, and how does it relate to the healing miracle performed by Peter and John?
options: It was a prominent entrance where a lame man was laid to beg, highlighting the public nature of the miracle
It was the private entrance reserved for priests, emphasizing the sanctity of the healing
It was a marketplace gate, symbolizing commerce and trade
It was the gate to the outer court where only Gentiles could enter
questions.correctAnswer: It was a prominent entrance where a lame man was laid to beg, highlighting the public nature of the miracle
questions.explanation: Acts 3:2 describes the lame man being laid daily at the gate called Beautiful to ask alms; the public setting emphasizes the miracle's impact and witnesses.

questions.question: In Acts 3:6, Peter says, 'Silver and gold have I none; but such as I have give I thee.' What does this statement reveal about the nature of the power used to heal the lame man?
options: The power comes from faith in Jesus Christ, not material wealth
Peter had hidden wealth but chose not to give it
The healing was performed through traditional temple offerings
The miracle was a result of monetary exchange
questions.correctAnswer: The power comes from faith in Jesus Christ, not material wealth
questions.explanation: Peter explicitly denies having silver or gold and attributes the healing power to Jesus Christ, emphasizing spiritual authority over material means (Acts 3:6).

questions.question: Acts 3:13 references the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. What is the theological significance of this connection in Peter's speech?
options: It connects Jesus to the covenant promises given to the patriarchs
It suggests a break from Jewish tradition
It emphasizes the rejection of Old Testament figures
It refers to a new god distinct from the God of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It connects Jesus to the covenant promises given to the patriarchs
questions.explanation: By invoking the God of the patriarchs, Peter roots Jesus' identity and mission in the fulfillment of God's longstanding covenant promises (Acts 3:13).

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure does Peter quote in Acts 3:22 to support his message about Jesus, and what is the significance of this quotation?
options: Moses; it foretells the coming of a prophet like him whom the people must hear
David; it prophesies the Messiah's kingdom
Isaiah; it predicts the suffering servant
Elijah; it signals the coming judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Moses; it foretells the coming of a prophet like him whom the people must hear
questions.explanation: Acts 3:22 cites Moses' prophecy about a prophet like himself whom God will raise up, identifying Jesus as that prophet and emphasizing obedience to him.

questions.question: How does the healing of the lame man in Acts 3 prefigure the resurrection power attributed to Jesus in verses 15 and 16?
options: The physical healing symbolizes the new life granted through Jesus’ resurrection
It merely demonstrates Peter's charisma without theological implications
The healing is unrelated to resurrection themes
It emphasizes the importance of temple rituals
questions.correctAnswer: The physical healing symbolizes the new life granted through Jesus’ resurrection
questions.explanation: The healing illustrates the transformative power of Jesus' resurrection, making the lame man walk as a sign of the life Jesus imparts (Acts 3:15-16).

questions.question: Acts 3:19 calls for repentance and conversion so that sins may be blotted out. How does this concept connect with Old Testament prophetic themes?
options: It echoes prophetic calls for return to God to receive forgiveness and restoration
It introduces a new concept absent from the Hebrew Scriptures
It contradicts the Old Testament emphasis on law alone
It focuses solely on ritual sacrifice without moral change
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes prophetic calls for return to God to receive forgiveness and restoration
questions.explanation: The call for repentance aligns with prophets like Isaiah and Jeremiah who urged Israel to turn back to God for mercy and renewal (Acts 3:19).

questions.question: True or False: In Acts 3:14, Peter accuses the people of rejecting 'the Holy One and the Just' and instead asking for a murderer to be released.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Peter clearly states that the people denied the Holy One and the Just and preferred to have a murderer granted to them (Acts 3:14).

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the structure of Peter's speech from Acts 3:12 to Acts 3:26, especially in the way he connects past prophecy and present fulfillment?
options: Chiasm, highlighting the central theme of Jesus' resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, highlighting the central theme of Jesus' resurrection
questions.explanation: Peter’s speech employs chiasm by framing the rejection and fulfillment of prophecy around Jesus’ resurrection, emphasizing its theological importance (Acts 3:12-26).

questions.question: In Acts 3:16, the phrase 'faith which is by him' uses a Greek construction. What is the significance of this phrase in understanding the source of healing and strength?
options: It indicates that faith comes through Jesus as the mediator of healing
It suggests faith is independent of Jesus
It implies healing comes from human effort
It denotes faith solely from Peter and John’s power
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates that faith comes through Jesus as the mediator of healing
questions.explanation: The Greek phrase emphasizes that faith is accessed through Jesus, making Him the source of the healing power (Acts 3:16).

questions.question: How does Peter's reference to 'the times of restitution of all things' in Acts 3:21 relate to Jewish eschatology and prophetic expectation?
options: It alludes to the restoration and fulfillment of God’s promises as foretold by the prophets
It refers to a political revolution against Rome
It describes the building of a new temple in Jerusalem
It indicates the end of the Jewish covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It alludes to the restoration and fulfillment of God’s promises as foretold by the prophets
questions.explanation: The phrase connects with Jewish expectations of a coming era where God restores creation and fulfills prophetic promises (Acts 3:21).

questions.question: What role does the concept of 'seed' play in Peter's message in Acts 3:25, and how does it connect with Genesis 12:3?
options: It refers to Jesus as the promised offspring through whom all nations are blessed
It signifies agricultural abundance unrelated to the covenant
It indicates the literal descendants of Abraham only
It denies any universal blessing to the nations
questions.correctAnswer: It refers to Jesus as the promised offspring through whom all nations are blessed
questions.explanation: Peter invokes the covenant with Abraham that all families would be blessed through his seed, identifying Jesus as that seed (Acts 3:25; Genesis 12:3).

questions.question: In Acts 3:17, Peter says that the people acted through ignorance. How does this reflect a common biblical motif regarding sin and guilt?
options: Ignorance can mitigate guilt but does not excuse sin
Sin is only committed with full knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: Ignorance can mitigate guilt but does not excuse sin
questions.explanation: Peter acknowledges ignorance as a factor but still calls for repentance, reflecting biblical themes where ignorance lessens but does not remove accountability (Acts 3:17).

questions.question: Which theme from Isaiah is echoed in Peter’s statement in Acts 3:20 about 'times of refreshing' coming from the presence of the Lord?
options: The theme of divine restoration and renewal
The theme of exile and destruction
The theme of judgment without hope
questions.correctAnswer: The theme of divine restoration and renewal
questions.explanation: The 'times of refreshing' echoes Isaiah's visions of restoration and renewal following repentance and divine intervention (Acts 3:19-20).

questions.question: How does the mention of Solomon’s porch in Acts 3:11 provide historical and cultural context for the setting of the healing event?
options: It situates the event in a well-known public area of the temple complex where many gathered
It suggests the event took place in a private chamber
It indicates the healing occurred outside Jerusalem
It refers to a non-Jewish place of worship
questions.correctAnswer: It situates the event in a well-known public area of the temple complex where many gathered
questions.explanation: Solomon's porch was a prominent area in the temple where people gathered, making the healing a public and highly visible event (Acts 3:11).

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 3:23, anyone who does not listen to the prophet like Moses will be destroyed from among the people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 3:23 states that every soul who will not hear the prophet like Moses shall be destroyed from among the people.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What time of day were Peter and John going to the temple when they encountered the lame man?
questions.correctAnswer: The ninth hour
questions.explanation: Acts 3:1 states that Peter and John went to the temple at the ninth hour, which was the hour of prayer. This corresponds with Jewish prayer times as seen in Daniel 6:10 and Mark 15:34. It emphasizes the practice of prayer at set times in the early church.

questions.question: What was the condition of the man who was healed by Peter and John at the Beautiful gate?
questions.correctAnswer: Lame from birth
questions.explanation: Acts 3:2 explains that the man was lame from his mother's womb. This highlights the miraculous nature of his healing, as healing a congenital infirmity demonstrates divine power, consistent with Jesus healing congenital conditions (John 9:1-7).

questions.question: What did Peter say he had to give the lame man instead of silver and gold?
options: The name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth
questions.correctAnswer: The name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth
questions.explanation: In Acts 3:6, Peter explicitly says he has no silver or gold but gives healing in the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth. This underscores the power of Jesus' name for salvation and healing, a theme reiterated in Philippians 2:9-11 and John 14:13-14.

questions.question: What immediate effect did Peter's healing have on the lame man's body?
options: His feet and ankle bones received strength
questions.correctAnswer: His feet and ankle bones received strength
questions.explanation: Acts 3:7 states that the man's feet and ankle bones received strength immediately, enabling him to walk. This physical restoration serves as a sign of spiritual restoration, echoing Jesus' miracles in Matthew 11:5 and Isaiah 35:6.

questions.question: How did the healed man respond after being made whole?
options: He walked, leaped, and praised God
He immediately preached to the crowd
He went to the priests for cleansing
questions.correctAnswer: He walked, leaped, and praised God
questions.explanation: Acts 3:8 describes the healed man leaping up, walking, and praising God. This joyful response shows gratitude and recognition of God's power, similar to the healed leper in Luke 17:15-16 praising God.

questions.question: What was the public's reaction to the lame man's healing at the temple?
options: They were filled with wonder and amazement
They accused Peter and John of sorcery
questions.correctAnswer: They were filled with wonder and amazement
questions.explanation: Acts 3:10 records that the people were amazed and filled with wonder at the miracle. This reaction aligns with other miraculous healings in the Bible which provoke awe and lead to evangelistic opportunities (Mark 2:12, Luke 5:26).

questions.question: What does Peter say is NOT the source of the man's healing?
options: The money given by the crowd
questions.correctAnswer: Their own power or holiness
questions.explanation: Acts 3:12 clarifies that Peter denies that their own power or holiness made the man walk, attributing the miracle to God's power through Jesus Christ. This reflects humility and theological accuracy consistent with 1 Corinthians 1:27-31.

questions.question: According to Peter, who has God glorified as the source of the healing?
questions.correctAnswer: His Son Jesus
questions.explanation: Acts 3:13 states that God glorified His Son Jesus, who was delivered up and denied. This affirms the Christological doctrine of Jesus as the glorified Son of God (John 3:16, Hebrews 1:3).

questions.question: What accusation does Peter make against the people concerning Jesus?
options: They denied and killed the Holy One and the Just
They worshipped idols instead of Jesus
They refused to enter the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They denied and killed the Holy One and the Just
questions.explanation: Acts 3:14-15 accuse the people of denying the Holy One and the Just and killing the Prince of life. This highlights human sinfulness and rejection of the Messiah, consistent with Isaiah 53 and Psalm 22 prophecies.

questions.question: How does Peter describe the role of faith in the healing of the lame man?
options: Faith in Jesus' name made the man strong
The man's own faith healed him
Faith in the temple's power healed him
questions.correctAnswer: Faith in Jesus' name made the man strong
questions.explanation: Acts 3:16 explains that faith in Jesus' name gave the man perfect soundness, emphasizing the necessity of faith for salvation and healing, echoing Hebrews 11:6 and Romans 4:20-21.

questions.question: What does Peter say about the ignorance of those who rejected Jesus?
options: They were deceived by false prophets
They were fully aware of their sin
questions.correctAnswer: They acted through ignorance
questions.explanation: Acts 3:17 shows Peter acknowledging that the people and their rulers acted in ignorance when they rejected Jesus. This aligns with the biblical theme of ignorance mitigating guilt but not excusing sin (1 Timothy 1:13).

questions.question: What Old Testament truth does Peter say has been fulfilled by Christ's suffering?
questions.correctAnswer: Prophecies that Christ should suffer
questions.explanation: Acts 3:18 affirms that God's prophets foretold Christ's suffering, which has been fulfilled. This corresponds to Isaiah 53 and Psalm 22, showing continuity between Old and New Testament revelation.

questions.question: What does Peter urge the people to do for their sins to be blotted out?
questions.correctAnswer: Repent and be converted
questions.explanation: In Acts 3:19, Peter calls for repentance and conversion for sins to be blotted out, emphasizing the necessity of turning from sin as taught in Ezekiel 18:30-32 and 2 Chronicles 7:14.

questions.question: What future event does Peter link to repentance and conversion in Acts 3?
options: Times of refreshing from the presence of the Lord
The building of the third temple
questions.correctAnswer: Times of refreshing from the presence of the Lord
questions.explanation: Acts 3:19-20 mentions that repentance will bring times of refreshing from the Lord's presence, indicating eschatological renewal consistent with Joel 2:28-32 and Isaiah 40:3-5.

questions.question: Who does Peter say God will send back before the times of restitution?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Acts 3:20-21 foretells the sending of Jesus Christ before the restoration of all things, linking to messianic expectations in Daniel 7:13-14 and Isaiah 9:6-7.
